message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Artificial life: The coming evolution
Paper Abstract: Within fifty to a hundred years a new class of organisms is likely to emerge. These organisms will be artificial in the sense that they will originally be designed by humans. However, they will reproduce, and will evolve into something other than their initial form; they will be alive'' under any reasonable definition of the word. These organisms will evolve in a fundamentally different manner than contemporary biological organisms, since their reproduction will be under at least partial conscious control, giving it a Lamarckian component. The pace of evolutionary change consequently will be extremely rapid. The advent of artificial life will be the most significant historical event since the emergence of human beings. The impact on humanity and the biosphere could be enormous, larger than the industrial revolution, nuclear weapons, or environmental pollution. We must take steps now to shape the emergence of artificial organisms; they have potential to be either the ugliest terrestrial disaster, or the most beautiful creation of humanity. 22 refs., 3 figs.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Here are the search results for "evolution":

The search returned a diverse range of results on the topic of evolution. Here's a summary of the main categories:

## Biological Evolution
Evolution in organisms occurs through changes in heritable characteristics—the inherited characteristics of an organism.(no content)Evolution by natural selection is established by observable facts about living organisms: (1) more offspring are often produced than can possibly survive; (2) traits vary among individuals with respect to their morphology, physiology, and behaviour; (3) different traits confer different rates of survival and reproduction; and (4) traits can be passed from generation to generation.

Web search results for query: "artificial life"

Links: [{"title":"Artificial life - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_life"},{"title":"History of artificial life - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_artificial_life"},{"title":"Artificial Life (journal) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_Life_(journal)"},{"title":"Quantum artificial life - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_artificial_life"},{"title":"Category:Artificial life - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Artificial_life"},{"title":"Artificial creation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_creation"},{"title":"Christopher Langton - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christopher_Langton"},{"title":"Artificial chemistry - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_chemistry"},{"title":"Avida - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Avida"},{"title":"Max Tegmark - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Max_Tegmark"}]

Here's what I found about artificial life:

## Overview

Artificial Life (ALife) is a field of study wherein researchers examine systems related to natural life, its processes, and its evolution, through the use of simulations with computer models, robotics, and biochemistry.(no content)The discipline was named by Christopher Langton, an American computer scientist, in 1986.(no content)In 1987, Langton organized the first conference on the field, in Los Alamos, New Mexico.

## Three Main Approaches

There are three main kinds of alife, named for their approaches: soft, from software; hard, from hardware; and wet, from biochemistry.

## Research Goals

Artificial life researchers study traditional biology by trying to recreate aspects of biological phenomena. Artificial life studies the fundamental processes of living systems in artificial environments in order to gain a deeper understanding of the complex information processing that define such systems.

## Unique Approach

The modeling philosophy of artificial life strongly differs from traditional modeling by studying not only "life as we know it" but also "life as it could be". In contrast, an alife modeling approach will generally seek to decipher the most simple and general principles underlying life and implement them in a simulation.

The field is interdisciplinary, spanning computer science, biology, and has applications in areas like economics and archaeology.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Here are the web search results for "organism":

## Definition

An organism is any living thing that functions as an individual. However, the concept of an individual is difficult, and several criteria have been proposed to define what constitutes an organism.

## Types of Organisms

Organisms can be classified into different categories:

- A unicellular organism is an organism that consists of a single cell, unlike a multicellular organism that consists of multiple cells.
- Organisms fall into two general categories: prokaryotic organisms and eukaryotic organisms. Most prokaryotes are unicellular and are classified into bacteria and archaea. Many eukaryotes are multicellular, but some are unicellular such as protozoa, unicellular algae, and unicellular fungi.

## Size Range

The smallest organisms vary by measurement method. Guinness World Records recognizes Nanoarchaeum equitans as the smallest living organism.(no content)Prasinophyte algae of the genus Ostreococcus are the smallest free-living eukaryote, with a single cell measuring 800 nm across.

## Diversity and Population

Estimates on the number of Earth's current species range from 10 million to 14 million, of which about 1.2 million have been documented and over 86 percent have not yet been described.

I've completed the web search for "reproduction biology." Here's a summary of what was found:

## Overview of Reproduction Biology

Reproductive biology includes both sexual and asexual reproduction.(no content)Reproduction is the biological process by which new individual organisms – "offspring" – are produced from their "parent" or parents.

## Two Types of Reproduction

**Asexual Reproduction:** In asexual reproduction, an organism can reproduce without the involvement of another organism.(no content)By asexual reproduction, an organism creates a genetically similar or identical copy of itself.

**Sexual Reproduction:** Sexual reproduction is a type of reproduction that involves a complex life cycle in which a gamete (haploid reproductive cells, such as a sperm or egg cell) with a single set of chromosomes combines with another gamete to produce a zygote that develops into an organism composed of cells with two sets of chromosomes (diploid).(no content)Sexual reproduction is the most common life cycle in multicellular eukaryotes, such as animals, fungi and plants.

## Human Reproductive Biology

Human reproductive biology is primarily controlled through hormones, which send signals to the human reproductive structures to influence growth and maturation. The search results also cover related fields like human reproductive ecology, which studies how human reproductive processes respond to ecological variables.

The search found numerous academic resources on this topic, including peer-reviewed journals dedicated to reproductive biology research.

I've completed the web search for "reproduction biology." Here's a summary of what was found:

## Overview of Reproduction Biology

Reproductive biology includes both sexual and asexual reproduction.(no content)Reproduction is the biological process by which new individual organisms – "offspring" – are produced from their "parent" or parents.

## Two Types of Reproduction

**Asexual Reproduction:** In asexual reproduction, an organism can reproduce without the involvement of another organism.(no content)By asexual reproduction, an organism creates a genetically similar or identical copy of itself.

**Sexual Reproduction:** Sexual reproduction is a type of reproduction that involves a complex life cycle in which a gamete (haploid reproductive cells, such as a sperm or egg cell) with a single set of chromosomes combines with another gamete to produce a zygote that develops into an organism composed of cells with two sets of chromosomes (diploid).(no content)Sexual reproduction is the most common life cycle in multicellular eukaryotes, such as animals, fungi and plants.

## Human Reproductive Biology

Human reproductive biology is primarily controlled through hormones, which send signals to the human reproductive structures to influence growth and maturation. The search results also cover related fields like human reproductive ecology, which studies how human reproductive processes respond to ecological variables.

The search found numerous academic resources on this topic, including peer-reviewed journals dedicated to reproductive biology research.

I've completed the web search for "Lamarckism inheritance." Here are the key findings:

## Definition

Lamarckism, also known as Lamarckian inheritance or neo-Lamarckism, is the notion that an organism can pass on to its offspring physical characteristics that the parent organism acquired through use or disuse during its lifetime.

## Historical Context

The inheritance of acquired characteristics was proposed in ancient times and remained a current idea for many centuries, accepted for at least 2,200 years before Lamarck's time.(no content)The modern era generally remembers Lamarck for this theory, which he described in his 1809 Philosophie zoologique.

## Scientific Standing

Mendelian genetics supplanted the notion of inheritance of acquired traits, eventually leading to the development of the modern synthesis, and the general abandonment of Lamarckism in biology.(no content)Many researchers from the 1860s onwards attempted to find evidence for Lamarckian inheritance, but these have all been explained away, either by other mechanisms such as genetic contamination or as fraud.

## Modern Developments

In the 21st century, experimental results in the fields of epigenetics, genetics, and somatic hypermutation demonstrated the possibility of transgenerational epigenetic inheritance of traits acquired by the previous generation.(no content)In the field of epigenetics, evidence is growing that soft inheritance plays a part in the changing of some organisms' phenotypes through methylation and other mechanisms, with many epigenetic changes being heritable to a degree.

I've retrieved comprehensive search results about environmental pollution. Here's an overview of the key information:

## Definition and Types

Pollution is the introduction of contaminants into the natural environment that cause harm.(no content)Pollution can take the form of any substance (solid, liquid, or gas) or energy (such as radioactivity, heat, sound, or light).

## Major Forms of Pollution

The search results identify several major types of environmental pollution:

- **Air Pollution**: Air pollution is the release of chemicals and particulates into the atmosphere, with common gaseous pollutants including carbon monoxide, sulfur dioxide, chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) and nitrogen oxides produced by industry and motor vehicles.

- **Water Pollution**: Marine pollution occurs when substances used or spread by humans, such as industrial, agricultural, and residential waste enter the ocean and cause harmful effects.

- **Plastic Pollution**: Plastic pollution is the accumulation of plastic objects and particles (e.g. plastic bottles, bags and microbeads) in the Earth's environment that adversely affects humans, wildlife and their habitat.

- **Soil Contamination**: Soil contamination occurs when chemicals are released by spill or underground leakage, with among the most significant soil contaminants being hydrocarbons, heavy metals, MTBE, herbicides, pesticides and chlorinated hydrocarbons.

## Health and Global Impact

In 2019, pollution killed approximately nine million people worldwide (about one in six deaths that year); about three-quarters of these deaths were caused by air pollution.

I've completed a web search for "industrial revolution." Here are the key findings:

## Overview

The Industrial Revolution was a transitional period of the global economy toward more widespread, efficient and stable manufacturing processes, succeeding the Second Agricultural Revolution.

## Historical Timeline

The Industrial Revolution began in Britain in the 1780s according to some historians, while others held it occurred between 1760 and 1830.(no content)Rapid adoption of mechanized textiles spinning occurred in Britain in the 1780s, and high rates of growth in steam power and iron production occurred after 1800.

## Key Phases

The Industrial Revolution is typically divided into distinct phases:
- **First Industrial Revolution**: Marked by a transition from hand production methods to machines through the use of steam power and water power, occurring between 1760 and 1820, or 1840 in Europe and the United States.
- **Second Industrial Revolution**: A phase of rapid scientific discovery, standardisation, mass production and industrialisation from the late 19th century into the early 20th century.

## Impact and Significance

The standard of living for most in the Western world began to increase consistently for the first time.(no content)Economic historians agree that the onset of the Industrial Revolution is the most important event in human history, comparable only to the adoption of agriculture with respect to material advancement.

I've completed the web search for "nuclear weapons" and here's a comprehensive overview of the key information found:

## What are Nuclear Weapons?

A nuclear weapon is an explosive device that derives its destructive force from nuclear reactions, either nuclear fission (fission or atomic bomb) or a combination of fission and nuclear fusion reactions (thermonuclear weapon), producing a nuclear explosion.(no content)Both bomb types release large quantities of energy from relatively small amounts of matter.

## Effects and Destruction

Effects of nuclear weapons include extreme heat and ionizing radiation, firestorms, radioactive nuclear fallout, an electromagnetic pulse, and a radar blackout.(no content)Yields in the low kilotons can devastate cities.

## Historical Development

The first nuclear weapons were developed by the United States in collaboration with the United Kingdom and Canada during World War II in the Manhattan Project.(no content)Nuclear weapons have been used twice in war, in the 1945 atomic bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki that killed between 150,000 and 246,000 people.

## Current Nuclear Powers

There are currently nine sovereign states that are generally understood to possess nuclear weapons, though only eight formally acknowledge possessing them.(no content)In order of first successful nuclear test, the world's nine nuclear-armed states are the United States (1945), Russia (1949), the United Kingdom (1952), France (1960), China (1964), India (1974), Pakistan (1998), and North Korea (2006); Israel is believed to have acquired nuclear weapons around 1967, but has never openly tested or formally acknowledged having them.

## Global Stockpiles

According to the Federation of American Scientists (FAS), there are 12,331 nuclear warheads in the world and approximately 3,904 of these are active, as of 2025.

## Summary

I've successfully completed the analysis of the paper "Artificial life: The coming evolution". Here's what was accomplished:

**Paper Classification:** `contribution` - The paper proposes a novel vision of artificial organisms that will be designed, reproduce, and evolve.

**Extracted Triples (8 total):**

1. **Artificial life** (proposes) - The core concept being introduced
2. **Evolution** (uses) - Foundational biological process
3. **Reproduction** (uses) - Central to artificial life definition
4. **Lamarckism** (uses) - Explicitly mentioned as a component of artificial organism evolution
5. **Organism** (uses) - The fundamental entity class
6. **Industrial Revolution** (uses) - Used for comparative impact assessment
7. **Nuclear weapon** (uses) - Used for comparative impact assessment
8. **Pollution** (uses) - Used for comparative impact assessment
